what: Processing socioeconomic, demographic and health variables
title: Get started
text: separate functions focus processing different theme socioeconomic, demographic health variables. See vignette("covariate_data"). Note order cleaning functions applied can matter - functions use variables cleaned others.
code: library(magrittr)  temp <- read_2017(root = root_dir) %>%   clean_age %>%   clean_family %>%   clean_demographic %>%    clean_education %>%   clean_economic_status %>%   clean_income %>%   clean_health_and_bio

title: Get started
text: Detailed description clean alcohol data given vignette("alcohol_data"). example, workflow plot frquency drinking among people drank 2017.
code: library(magrittr) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2)  # Frequency of drinking in 2017 among drinkers root_dir <- "/Volumes/Shared/" #root_dir <- "X:/"  read_2017(root = root_dir) %>%   clean_age %>%   clean_demographic %>%   alc_drink_now_allages %>%   filter(age < 90, age >= 8, drinks_now == "drinker") %>%   group_by(imd_quintile, age_cat) %>%    summarise(av_freq = mean(drink_freq_7d, na.rm = T)) %>%    ggplot(aes(x = imd_quintile, y = av_freq, fill = age_cat)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", position = "dodge") +   theme_minimal() +   ylab("average number of days drink in a week")

what: Clean all years of smoking and alcohol data
title: Get started
text: See vignette("smoking_data").
code: library(magrittr)  # Wrap the individual cleaning functions in another function for applying to each year  cleandata <- function(data) {      data %<>%     clean_age %>%     clean_demographic %>%      clean_education %>%     clean_economic_status %>%     clean_family %>%     clean_income %>%     clean_health_and_bio %>%     smk_status %>%     smk_former %>%     smk_life_history %>%     smk_amount %>%     alc_drink_now_allages %>%     alc_weekmean_adult %>%     alc_sevenday_adult %>%     alc_sevenday_child %>%          select_data(       ages = 12:89,       years = 2001:2017,              # variables to retain       keep_vars = c("wt_int", "psu", "cluster", "year", "quarter",                     "age", "age_cat", "sex", "imd_quintile",                     "ethnicity_4cat", "ethnicity_2cat",                     "degree", "relationship_status", "employ2cat", "social_grade", "kids", "income5cat",                     "nssec3_lab", "man_nonman", "activity_lstweek", "eduend4cat",                                          "hse_cancer", "hse_endocrine", "hse_heart", "hse_mental", "hse_nervous", "hse_eye", "hse_ear", "hse_respir",                      "hse_disgest", "hse_urinary", "hse_skin", "hse_muscskel", "hse_infect", "hse_blood",                                          "weight", "height", "bmi",                                          "cig_smoker_status", "years_since_quit", "years_reg_smoker", "cig_ever",                     "cigs_per_day", "smoker_cat", "banded_consumption", "cig_type", "time_to_first_cig",                     "smk_start_age", "smk_stop_age", "censor_age", "giveup_smk",                                          "drinks_now",                      "drink_freq_7d", "n_days_drink", "peakday", "binge_cat",                     "beer_units", "wine_units", "spirit_units", "rtd_units",                      "weekmean",                      "perc_spirit_units", "perc_wine_units", "perc_rtd_units", "perc_beer_units",                      "drinker_cat",                      "spirits_pref_cat", "wine_pref_cat", "rtd_pref_cat", "beer_pref_cat",                      "total_units7_ch"       ),              # The variables that must have complete cases       complete_vars = c("age", "sex", "year", "quarter", "psu", "cluster")     )      return(data) }  # Read and clean each year of data and bind them together in one big dataset data <- combine_years(list(   cleandata(read_2001(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2002(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2003(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2004(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2005(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2006(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2007(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2008(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2009(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2010(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2011(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2012(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2013(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2014(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2015(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2016(root = root_dir)),   cleandata(read_2017(root = root_dir)) ))  # clean the survey weights data <- clean_surveyweights(data)

title: Data check: Alcohol consumption in the Scottish Health Survey
text: Scottish Health Survey (SHeS) annual series surveys health health-related behaviours private households Scotland carried annually since 2008 (1995, 1998 2003). source data alcohol consumption used inform alcohol component Sheffield Tobacco Alcohol Policy Modelling. survey asks respondents volume certain types drinks bought consumed certain time period. volumes standardised converting alcohol units (one UK standard unit = 10ml pure ethanol). conversion reported volumes units based assumptions average alcohol content (ABV) different types drink. generally accepted self-reported data underestimates actual consumption much 50% (Stockwell et al. 2004). data check investigate magnitude underestimation potential biases introduced. Scottish Health Survey estimates alcohol consumption people age 16 . Participants reported drank asked often past 12 months drink six different types alcoholic drink: normal beer, lager, stout, cider shandy strong beer, lager, stout cider sherry Martini spirits liqueurs wine alcoholic soft drinks (alcopops) questions, average number days per week participant drunk estimated. question asks much drink type usually drunk occasion. main report Scottish Health Survey 2018 volume 1 (McLean et al. 2018) gives conversion factors used convert quantity-frequency survey questions estimated units average weekly alcohol consumption.  Table 1. Excerpt Section 3.2.3 p 78 main report volume 1 Scottish Health Survey 2018.  SHeS data processed use STAPM modelling standardised version controlled R code functions hseclean R package. title: Alcohol average weekly consumption (adults) — alc_weekmean_adult
text: beer_units - average weekly units beer wine_units - average weekly units wine spirit_units - average weekly units spirits rtd_units - average weekly units alcopops weekmean - total average weekly units perc_spirit_units - percentage consumption spirits perc_wine_units - percentage consumption wine perc_rtd_units - percentage consumption alcopops perc_beer_units - percentage consumption beer drinker_cat - categories average weekly consumption spirits_pref_cat - whether drink, drinks mostly drinks spirits wine_pref_cat - whether drink, drinks mostly drinks wine rtd_pref_cat - whether drink, drinks mostly drinks alcopops beer_pref_cat - whether drink, drinks mostly drinks beer

title: Alcohol average weekly consumption (adults) — alc_weekmean_adult
text: calculation following steps: Convert categorical variables numeric variables frequency beverage typically consumed (normal beer, strong beer, spirits, sherry, wine, alcopops). Convert reported volumes usually consumed (e.g. small glass, large glass) volumes ml, using beverage size assumptions . , variations recording among years interview self-complete questionnaire accounted . Combine volumes (ml) usually consumed frequency consumption give average volume beverage type drunk week (assuming constant consumption across year). Convert expected volumes beverage consumed week UK standard units alcohol consumed, using alcohol content assumptions . Collapse normal strong beer single "beer" variable summing units. Collapse wine sherry single "wine" variable summing units. Calculate total weekly units summing across beverage categories. Calculate beverage "preference vector" - percentage total consumption contributed consumption four beverage types (beer, wine, spirits, alcopops). Cap total units consumed week 300 units, assuming already high level consumption estimates variation consumption less reliable. Categorise average weekly consumption "abstainer", "lower_risk" (less 14 units/week), "increasing_risk" (greater equal 14 units/week less 35 units/week women, less 50 units/week men), "higher_risk". Categorise beverage preferences - four beverages, "does_not_drink", "drinks_some" (less equal 50% consumption), "mostly_drinks". 2007 new questions added asking glass size used wine consumed. Therefore post HSE 2007 unit calculations directly comparable previous years' data.
